results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This short silent film consists of a staged interview between a man and a woman, seated in a 1950s or 1960s lounge setting with diamond patterned wallpaper in the background. There is also a short snippet of crowds of people at an exhibition.

This film was made on Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This short film shows scenes of a holiday in Phillip Island, a popular holiday destination south-east of Melbourne, Victoria.

This film was made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 views over the water
00:02:15:00 penguins and seals on the rocks
00:04:15:00 exploring the rock pools
00:05:00:00 plume of water crashing against the rocks
00:06:06:00 a short snippet of an Aboriginal woman

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film takes place in Idar-Oberstein, a town in the Birkenfeld district in Rhineland-Palatinate, Germany, which is traditionally known as a gemstone town. The film contains footage of the town’s workshops, including scenes of men making detailed cameo carvings and using large grinding wheels. It also features the water mills used to power the workshop from the river Nahe.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:15:00 man working on a small gemstone on a grinding wheel
00:01:14:00 making a carved cameo
00:03:57:00 jewellers in the workshop
00:04:09:00 a display box filled with cameos
00:05:16:00 a water mill used to power the workshop machines
00:06:20:00 a large grinding wheel being used on slabs of stone
00:07:22:00 polishing on emery wheels
00:08:42:00 water mill surrounded by old stone walls

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film depicts a trip to Andamooka Opal Field in South Australia. Andamooka was established following the discovery of opal there in 1930, and largely consisted of scattered miners’ camps. The film includes footage of the mines, the miners, the dugouts and shacks that comprised the settlement, and close-ups of opals in display cases.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:29:00 bus ride through the South Australian outback
00:02:19:00 handpainted sign reading ‘Welcome to Andamooka Opal Field’
00:03:01:00 mine shafts
00:03:15:00 group of people examining the opal field, including a young girl in a pink pinafore
00:04:51:00 a mine shaft with pulley system
00:05:20:00 man skipping down the hill
00:05:33:00 the Andamooka Post Office
00:06:33:00 shanty structures
00:07:00:00 Aboriginal children playing
00:08:30:00 a man being hoisted out of a mine shaft
00:09:41:00 two miners chatting
00:10:11:00 close-ups of opals in display cases
00:12:26:00 sunset over the opal fields

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is entitled ‘Daddy wouldn’t buy me a Bow-Bow’ and is credited to Tibor and Merna Koller. It is staged as a narrative film, following a teenage girl, presumably the couple’s daughter, visiting a kennel to buy a puppy and bringing it home.

This film was made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title card ‘Daddy wouldn’t buy me a Bow-Bow’ followed by ‘Produced by Tibor & Merna Koller 1968’
00:00:29:00 calendar indicating the date 28 November 1968
00:00:36:00 footage of a teenage girl sleeping, interspersed with footage of puppies, indicating she is dreaming
00:01:37:00 the newspaper boy arrives on a bicycle
00:02:15:00 sign ‘Victorian Animal Aid Trust’
00:02:31:00 girl patting puppies through a diamond wire fence
00:04:39:00 girl and puppy playing in the front yard of their house
00:04:51:00 giving the dog a bath in the laundry sink
00:06:00:00 having a nap in the sun together
00:06:11:00 title card ‘The End, Daddy DID buy me a Bow-Bow’

results.title: Stelarc Moving Image Collection
results.brief_description:
The Stelarc Collection is the moving image archive of Australian performance artist Stelarc. The collection consists of documentation of events and performances throughout the career of the pioneering body artist from the 1970s to the 2000s. Renowned for pushing his body to its limits through durational performance, body modification and surgical enhancement, Stelarc has established a decades-long practice that explores the intersection between the human body and technology, proposing a post-human understanding of the world. This unique archive of video and photographic documentation spans the artist’s early hook suspensions and internal body probes to performances with a robotic third arm and experiments in virtual realities.

The collection is housed on a variety of formats used since the introduction of video in the 1970s, including reel-to-reel tape, VHS, U-Matic, SP Betacam and Mini DV. These variable formats are currently being digitised to ensure the preservation and legacy of the artist’s archive.

The Stelarc Collection has been generously donated to ACMI by the artist through the Cultural Gifts Program.

This unique archive of video and photographic documentation spans the artist’s early hook suspensions and internal body probes to performances with a robotic third arm and experiments in virtual realities.

The collection is housed on a variety of formats used since the introduction of video in the 1970s, including reel-to-reel tape, VHS, U-Matic, SP Betacam and Mini DV. These variable formats are currently being digitised to ensure the preservation and legacy of the artist’s archive.

The Stelarc Collection has been generously donated to ACMI by the artist through the Cultural Gifts Program.
description_for_label:
The Stelarc Collection is the moving image archive of Australian performance artist Stelarc. The collection consists of documentation of events and performances throughout the career of the pioneering body artist from the 1970s to the 2000s. Renowned for pushing his body to its limits through durational performance, body modification and surgical enhancement, Stelarc has established a decades-long practice that explores the intersection between the human body and technology, proposing a post-human understanding of the world. This unique archive of video and photographic documentation spans the artist’s early hook suspensions and internal body probes to performances with a robotic third arm and experiments in virtual realities.

The collection is housed on a variety of formats used since the introduction of video in the 1970s, including reel-to-reel tape, VHS, U-Matic, SP Betacam and Mini DV. These variable formats are currently being digitised to ensure the preservation and legacy of the artist’s archive.

The Stelarc Collection has been generously donated to ACMI by the artist through the Cultural Gifts Program.

results.title: Unreserved : stories from Truganina Explosives Reserve
results.brief_description:
Unreserved : Stories from Truganina Explosives Reserve is the culmination of a community arts project involving local residents and some of Melbourne’s up and coming designers. Based on oral histories collected from local residents who have a connection with this historic site, a series of animations have been produced recreating some of the unique stories of this site.
Truganina Explosives Reserve, one of Altona’s last intact historic sites, is located 26 kilometres west of the city, and nine kilometres from Williamstown on the shores of Port Phillip Bay. The reserve was established by the State Government in 1901 for the storage and handling of commercial explosives. After its closure in 1962, the reserve lay dormant for more than 25 years, protected from the outside world by the two and a half metre high galvanised fence.
In the 1990s, the reserve became the site of an intense community battle aimed at saving the site from redevelopment. The community embarked on a quest to save one of the western suburbs’ most significant historical and environmental locations, the site of an important early Australian industry.

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

This film captures some travels around Victoria. The Parsons take a trip from Wangaratta to Beechworth, down through Mount Buffalo to San Remo and Phillip Island on the south coast, and back up through the Dandenong Ranges and Healesville.

The film shows scenes of life in country towns of Victoria, including sporting and recreational events, the flooding of Ovens River, some beautiful footage of Phillip Island, the Australian Alps in autumn, and the Tesselaar Tulip Festival in Healesville.

The Parsons’ travels also take them to the Hume Dam, formerly known as the Hume Weir, which was a popular tourist destination during the 1940s and 50s.

A feature of the film is the flooded roads and paddocks of Wangaratta during the 1956 floods, which stemmed from major flooding in the Murray River.

Ted films road signs to indicate each stop on their travels.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 road sign ‘Wangaratta Please Slow Down’
00:00:13:00 the Wangaratta Flour Mills building
00:00:20:00 the Wangaratta Woollen Mills
00:00:28:00 swimmers - mostly children - at a water hole or river, and diving off a metal tower
00:01:00:00 a great example of a house with blinds against summer heat and 1950s style car
00:01:15:00 views of gladioli and daisies
00:03:30:00 grasshoppers swarming on the bowls club lawn
00:04:06:00 a man and woman walk with children and an old fashioned baby’s pram followed by children playing in a park playground
00:04:40:00 sign ‘Ovens River’ on a bridge filled with cars
00:04:50:00 1950s style trucks and cars drive through flooded roads
00:05:15:00 flooded paddocks
00:05:33:00 two men, one with two walking sticks, stroll over a bridge closed to traffic in the floods, followed by more views of the floods
00:06:07:00 young women in sports attire walk their bicycles across the bridge
00:06:30:00 scenes of tennis players playing on grass courts to crowds of onlookers, with willow and gum trees in background
00:08:38:00 road sign ‘Beechworth’ followed by views around the township, public gardens, flowers and trees
00:11:20:00 shimmering autumn leaves on a tree, with the trunk being shaken by a grinning friend
00:13:09:00 signpost for Gorge Road and One Tree Hill, a scenic drive and hiking area near Beechworth
00:14:11:00 cypress pine trees on the banks of the gorge
00:14:28:00 picnic beside the car surrounded by gum trees
00:15:24:00 road sign ‘Whitfield Please Slow Down’ followed by views of the surrounding landscape and hills
00:16:30:00 road sign ‘Porepunkah Please Slow Down’
00:17:52:00 Eurobin Falls in Mount Buffalo National Park
00:18:15:00 two women and a man waving from the other side of the waterfalls, water gushing over the rocks beside them
00:19:19:00 a man clambers on to a rock in the rushing water, three women looking on and laughing
00:21:00:00 golden poplar trees and cypress pines in autumn
00:23:48:00 friends on a footbridge, leaning over the railings
00:24:03:00 the same group, joined by another man, posing for the camera on a plank across the river
00:24:30:00 a 1950s style car drives along a country road, golden leaves on the trees
00:25:21:00 roadside picnic featuring great examples of picnic utensils of the period - orange thermoses and baskets
00:27:10:00 road sign ‘San Remo Please Slow Down’ followed by the bridge between San Remo and Phillip Island, Victoria
00:27:28:00 the neon San Remo Hotel sign, followed by brick exterior of the hotel
00:27:52 handpainted sign ‘Nobbies Road House’ followed by the road house on the Nobbies, a headland on Phillip Island
00:28:35:00 1950s style car parked on the shoreline, followed by scenes of the ocean off the headland
00:29:55:00 a wide surf beach with groups of people walking along the shore
00:30:19:00 two women and a men walk up from the shore holding hands
00:30:42:00 man fishing from the beach
00:31:00:00 koalas in a gum tree
00:32:46:00 a snake writhing on the ground, bleeding
00:33:16:00 drinking beer at the kitchen table with great printed curtains behind
00:34:25:00 the Isle of Wight Hotel in Cowes on Phillip Island, Victoria
00:34:46:00 canola flowers
00:36:25:00 a boy letting pigeons out of a cage on the coastline
00:36:56:00 a group of friends walking along the shore, wading in the shallows and playing
00:38:47:00 woman in a printed dress rolls a wooden crate across the sand
00:39:00:00 the group picnic on the beach, sitting on the bonnets of cars parked on the sand
00:39:19:00 grinning man in sunglasses cheers the camera
00:39:41:00 a 1950s emerald green Ford Prefect with touring club badges on the grille arrives at the picnic
00:40:08:00 road signs to Gembrook, Cockatoo and the Princes Highway indicate the Dandenong Ranges in Victoria
00:41:23:00 wooden bridge across the Yarra River
00:42:43 road sign ‘Healesville Please Slow Down’ followed by scenes of the town
00:43:24:00 sign for ‘The Sir Colin Mackenzie Sanctuary’, now the Healesville Sanctuary, followed by scenes of wildlife including emus, kangaroos, pelicans, wallabies, echidnas and peacocks
00:47:06:00 a brown snake with a frog in its mouth
00:51:04:00 close up of a woman’s feet wearing large wooden clogs
00:51:13:00 bunch of tulips in a hand
00:51:20:00 a field of tulips with a woman picking flowers wearing a traditional Dutch costume and spectators watching, at what we can take to be the Tesselaar Tulip Festival, established in 1954 in Healesville and held once a year
00:52:17:00 close up of tulips in the ground
00:54:28:00 sign for the ‘Hume Reservoir’, followed by scenes of the Hume Dam, formerly known as the Hume Weir
00:55:30:00 water rushing down the dam wall
00:57:28:00 people on the edge of the dam wall, watching the water from the top
00:58:24:00 scenes of turbulent water

group.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection]

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

This film, titled ‘Water into Power’, features a visit by Parsons and his two friends to the power stations of the Kiewa Hydro-Electric Scheme in the Victorian Alps. The film also shows a visit the Yallourn power station and open cut coal mine. Parsons uses title cards throughout to narrate his film for presentation.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title cards read ‘E.J. Parsons Presents’, ‘Water into Power’, followed by footage of water rushing from dam pipes
00:00:16:00 title card ‘On the road to Bright and Mt Beauty’
00:01:30:00 three men sharing a beer beside their car on a country road, one smoking a pipe
00:01:53:00 title card ‘Control gates to Kiewa Hydro-Electric Project’
00:03:06:00 fire danger sign with rating set to ‘High’
00:03:19:00 guard manually raising a boomgate for the car
00:03:31:00 title card ‘No. 4 Power Station’
00:03:53:00 control panels atthe power station
00:05:33:00 the men walking across boulders beside the dam, seen from a high vantage point
00:05:58:00 ‘Diagram of No. 3 Power Station’ followed by views of the exterior and interior of the power station
00:06:51:00 an illustration showing the proposed Pretty Valley Dam
00:07:08:00 title card ‘3rd January 1957’
00:07:13:00 the friends playing with snowballs in a patch of snow, despite the apparently mild weather
00:07:54:00 man feigns throwing a snowball at the camera
00:08:01:00 title card ‘The End’
00:08:23:00 Yallourn power station and coal mine
00:11:37:00 a coal train
results.description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

This film, titled ‘Water into Power’, features a visit by Parsons and his two friends to the power stations of the Kiewa Hydro-Electric Scheme in the Victorian Alps. The film also shows a visit the Yallourn power station and open cut coal mine. Parsons uses title cards throughout to narrate his film for presentation.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title cards read ‘E.J. Parsons Presents’, ‘Water into Power’, followed by footage of water rushing from dam pipes
00:00:16:00 title card ‘On the road to Bright and Mt Beauty’
00:01:30:00 three men sharing a beer beside their car on a country road, one smoking a pipe
00:01:53:00 title card ‘Control gates to Kiewa Hydro-Electric Project’
00:03:06:00 fire danger sign with rating set to ‘High’
00:03:19:00 guard manually raising a boomgate for the car
00:03:31:00 title card ‘No. 4 Power Station’
00:03:53:00 control panels atthe power station
00:05:33:00 the men walking across boulders beside the dam, seen from a high vantage point
00:05:58:00 ‘Diagram of No. 3 Power Station’ followed by views of the exterior and interior of the power station
00:06:51:00 an illustration showing the proposed Pretty Valley Dam
00:07:08:00 title card ‘3rd January 1957’
00:07:13:00 the friends playing with snowballs in a patch of snow, despite the apparently mild weather
00:07:54:00 man feigns throwing a snowball at the camera
00:08:01:00 title card ‘The End’
00:08:23:00 Yallourn power station and coal mine
00:11:37:00 a coal train

results.title: [The Three Stooges - forward. Volume 4]
results.brief_description: Three classic comedies featuring the famous “Three Stooges” including the fourth stooge, Shemp, in Studio Stoops. Stars Moe Howard, Larry Fine, Curly Howard and Shemp Howard.
